snippet: After investors flocked to its five-year debt offering, Athens said it was a sign that the country was succeeding in turning its economy around.
abstract: Pension funds, banks and other big money managers are snapping up billions of dollars of once-shunned Greek debt; Greece's return to bond market after four years adds to growing optimism that most troubled nations in euro zone are finally recovering from downturn; risky buying reflects near-insatiable appetite for higher-paying investments around globe.

byline.original: By LIZ ALDERMAN and LANDON THOMAS Jr
byline.contributor: Liz Alderman reported from Athens and Landon Thomas Jr. from Washington. Jack Ewing contributed reporting from Frankfurt and Niki Kitsantonis from Athens.

lead_paragraph: After investors flocked to its five-year debt offering, Athens said it was a sign that the country was succeeding in turning its economy around.

headline.main: Taking a Risk, Investors Snap Up Once-Shunned Greek Debt
headline.print_headline: Taking a Risk, Investors Snap Up Once-Shunned Greek Debt
